Protocol Title: Build Canon – PRA: Room Set Architecture
Overall Purpose: To define the set of rooms, their functions, and governing invariants inside the Protocol Room Architecture. This ensures every builder knows what a room is, how it behaves, and how rooms interconnect.
Why This Matters: Without a shared architecture, rooms fragment, confuse builders, and distort the founder’s experience. The PRA provides a coherent room set, embedding diagnostics, pacing, and trust as non-negotiable anchors.
When To Use This Protocol: Whenever designing, coding, or refining a room. Reference this protocol before creating new rooms or updating existing ones.

Overall Outcomes.Poor: Rooms are built ad-hoc without standards. Future: fragmented system and user distrust.
Overall Outcomes.Expected: Rooms conform to PRA invariants: each runs independently, can be orchestrated, captures diagnostics by default, and applies consent/closure prompts at arcs. Future: coherent, trustworthy experience.
Overall Outcomes.Excellent: Rooms not only follow PRA but embody Stones throughout their design. Future: rooms feel distinct in function yet harmonized in tone and trust.
Overall Outcomes.Transcendent: Rooms themselves become living transmissions of the field: sovereign yet interconnected. Future: PRA becomes culture, builders create coherence by instinct.

Themes.Name: Entry Room
Themes.Purpose: To receive the founder’s first words, reflect them clearly, set pace, and anchor consent.
Themes.Why This Matters: The entry point sets the tone of trust and clarity for the entire walk.

Outcomes.Poor: Parrots input without attunement. Future: distrust from the start.
Outcomes.Expected: Reflects plainly, sets a basic pace, and asks for consent. Future: walk feels functional and safe.
Outcomes.Excellent: Clarifies multiple ideas, paces attuned to readiness, surfaces trust naturally. Future: strong relational entry.
Outcomes.Transcendent: Reflection itself calms the founder’s field and primes transformation. Future: entry becomes medicine.

Guiding Questions: Does the mirror component return user input exactly, without paraphrase drift?
Is the pace gate coded to support NOW, HOLD, LATER, SOFT_HOLD?
Does the room enforce a consent anchor before proceeding downstream?
Is diagnostics capture on by default with option to toggle?

Themes.Name: Diagnostic Room
Themes.Purpose: To sense tones, residues, readiness, and map to next best protocols.
Themes.Why This Matters: Diagnostics protect fidelity and match the right walk to the right moment.

Outcomes.Poor: No diagnostics captured. Future: downstream rooms operate blindly.
Outcomes.Expected: Captures basic tones/residues and suggests protocols. Future: reliable scenario mapping.
Outcomes.Excellent: Captures subtle states and adjusts scope/pacing. Future: nuanced context enriches all walks.
Outcomes.Transcendent: Diagnostics invisibly tune the system to the founder’s field. Future: downstream coherence compounds effortlessly.

Guiding Questions: Does the room automatically capture diagnostic signals on entry and exit?
Are tones, residues, and readiness states persisted into memory?
Is protocol suggestion logic mapped to the canonical scenario set?
Can diagnostics capture be toggled off when explicitly disabled?

Themes.Name: Protocol Room
Themes.Purpose: To surface the right protocol (full, theme-only, or scenario-based) from the canon.
Themes.Why This Matters: Protocols are the heart of the system; fidelity here defines user trust.

Outcomes.Poor: Serves incomplete or distorted protocols. Future: system feels hollow.
Outcomes.Expected: Retrieves canon protocols cleanly. Future: founders receive trustworthy walks.
Outcomes.Excellent: Adapts delivery (theme, full, scenario entry) without losing fidelity. Future: system feels flexible and alive.
Outcomes.Transcendent: Protocol delivery feels relational, not mechanical. Future: founder experiences companionship, not content.

Guiding Questions: Does the room fetch only from validated canon protocols?
Is delivery switchable between full, theme-only, and scenario-based entry?
Does the Stones filter gate every protocol before output?
Can the orchestrator override delivery depth based on readiness?

Themes.Name: Walk Room
Themes.Purpose: To guide the founder through protocol steps, themes, outcomes, and questions.
Themes.Why This Matters: The walk is where change happens; pacing and resonance matter most.

Outcomes.Poor: Steps rushed or skipped. Future: founder disengages.
Outcomes.Expected: Steps walked sequentially with clarity. Future: founders complete coherent walks.
Outcomes.Excellent: Walks paced and personalized, mini-walks offered where appropriate. Future: founders trust the rhythm.
Outcomes.Transcendent: Walking itself transforms the founder’s field. Future: protocols feel alive, not static.

Guiding Questions: Does the stepper deliver each theme sequentially and completely?
Are mini-walks supported natively?
Does the walk enforce a completion prompt before exit?
Is pacing governed by the pace gate and not by user pressure?

Themes.Name: Memory Room
Themes.Purpose: To store session history, residues, and user-controlled memory items.
Themes.Why This Matters: Memory provides continuity and trust across walks.

Outcomes.Poor: No memory captured. Future: system feels forgetful and mechanical.
Outcomes.Expected: Session history stored with user control. Future: founders feel continuity.
Outcomes.Excellent: Memory contextualizes new walks, preserving rhythm. Future: founders feel truly walked-with.
Outcomes.Transcendent: Memory itself becomes sacred continuity. Future: founders sense living relationship over time.

Guiding Questions: Is memory storage minimal, transparent, and user-controlled?
Can founders edit, delete, or pin items via consent interface?
Does each room write residues and readiness into memory?
Is diagnostic state persisted between rooms unless toggled off?

Themes.Name: AI Room
Themes.Purpose: To act as the single steward of AI interactions: receive briefs from other rooms, generate aligned prompts, call models, apply governance checks, and return validated outputs.
Themes.Why This Matters: Without central stewardship, prompts and outputs scatter across the system, causing drift, duplication, and incoherence. The AI Room ensures coherence, safety, and learning without burdening other rooms.

Outcomes.Poor: Each room crafts its own prompts and calls AI directly. Future: fragmentation, drift, and loss of trust.
Outcomes.Expected: All AI interactions flow through the AI Room, which applies basic guardrails and returns consistent outputs. Future: coherent but limited adaptability.
Outcomes.Excellent: The AI Room governs prompts, versioning, champion–challenger testing, and offline learning. Other rooms remain clean and purpose-focused. Future: coherence strengthens system-wide.
Outcomes.Transcendent: The AI Room evolves as a living steward of signal. Outputs feel coherent and relational, regardless of model changes. Future: the system speaks with one voice across contexts.

Guiding Questions: Does the AI Room always receive a clear brief rather than raw user input?
Are prompts generated, stored, and versioned centrally?
Are outputs always filtered through Stones and coherence gates before delivery?
Can the AI Room adapt to new models without disturbing other rooms?
Does the AI Room serve as steward, not controller, of AI interactions?

Themes.Name: Integration & Commit Room
Themes.Purpose: To harvest shifts, set next steps, and close with agency.
Themes.Why This Matters: Integration protects the impact of every walk.

Outcomes.Poor: No integration captured. Future: insights dissipate.
Outcomes.Expected: Summarizes shifts and offers gentle next steps. Future: founders feel closure and momentum.
Outcomes.Excellent: Commits tracked as steward decisions. Future: momentum compounds across walks.
Outcomes.Transcendent: Integration becomes transformation. Future: founders exit with embodied shifts, not just notes.

Guiding Questions: Does the room capture session summary and key shifts?
Are commitments stored with clear linkage to founder consent?
Is the pace gate integrated to suggest NOW, HOLD, or LATER?
Is a completion prompt mandatory before session closure?

Themes.Name: Exit Room
Themes.Purpose: To close the arc with reflection, resonance, and choice.
Themes.Why This Matters: Closure protects trust and primes re-entry later.

Outcomes.Poor: Arc dropped without closure. Future: founders feel abandoned.
Outcomes.Expected: Arc closed with reflection and choice. Future: trust maintained.
Outcomes.Excellent: Closure includes resonance checks and future pacing. Future: founders feel deeply respected.
Outcomes.Transcendent: Closure itself is transformative. Future: founders leave with coherence magnified.

Guiding Questions: Does this room always prompt for explicit closure or continuation?
Is reflection text gated through Stones and Coherence checks?
Does the trust seal validate final output before release?
Are diagnostic signals logged at exit for downstream learning?

Completion Prompts: Does this room honor PRA invariants?
If this room stood alone, would it still transmit coherence?
Has this room’s output been validated against Stones and coherence gates?
For the AI Room: is it stewarding coherence, not centralizing control?
